text:
Looking for some advice and helpful comments from my Julia family.
1. I am not really enjoying my postdoc as much. It mainly stems from that the fact that my advisor is non-engaging and dosn't prioritize me. I have five first author papers that are just sitting on her desk (and also obsolete since they were covid19 related, and not relevant/novel anymore). I asked her for a recommendation letter for some TT jobs I applied too, and she still hasn't written me one. There is no mentorship nor an interest in my future career. Is being a postdoc really all about being a completely independent researcher?
2. I have been looking at moving to the industry since TT job market is so bad. However, I just can not shake the feeling that it will mark me as a failure to my current colleagues. More importantly, I just can not shake the feeling that *I will consider myself a failure.* 
Are these all normal feelings? I just have to deal with this anxiety somehow right?

text:
I'm sorry you're going through this. Regarding the seeing yourself as a failure thing, that's something I also think about a lot when I think about leaving physics. Being a physicist is a really big part of my personal identity.

On the other hand, I really just don't have the same level of emotional investment in physics as I used to have, whereas I find myself being drawn a lot to computer programming (as evidenced by the inordinate amount of time I spend in this community).

My plan for now is to finish my PhD and then re-evaluate, but I'm leaning very strongly towards software development once I leave.

I'll just say you're not alone in feeling this way and it's normal. But you have to look at what career is actually best for you, rather than what career is best for your ego or self identity.

I totally feel you. The feeling like a failure thing if you leave academia is totally relatable, but I've come to think of that culture as basically a defense mechanism - no one would put up with the extra work, extra stress, and (substantially) lower pay of academia if they weren't able to tell themselves that they were somehow better than the people who left.

Not that I'm a shining example - I'm still in academia too, though leaning further and further toward leaving. Also worth noting that everyone I know that left academica (which is most of my friends from grad school) are very happy with their choices

text:
Seems like many of us here are going through and have gone through similar things.  The brutal truth is: there are hardly any jobs in academia, and there are hardly any true research jobs in private industry.  There are plenty of extremely smart and capable people who couldn't get a worthwhile job even if they tried their hardest.  When opportunities are so scarce, you can do everything right and still lose just from bad luck.  It should not be this way, and it sucks.  I am constantly bemoaning the fact that society's goals seems so utterly pointless that it is nearly impossible to perform worthwhile work for a living.

There is no way around the fact that many of us will wind up in the traditional dumping ground of unwanted experts in software (and what is now called "data science").  I feel somewhat lucky in that I have always absolutely loved computers and computing for its own sake, so it makes my current job as a data scientist bearable and somewhat enjoyable, even if I think the ultimate purpose of nearly all firms that would possibly hire me are at best inane and at worst directly opposed to my self interest.

As much as I wish I were still doing physics, I don't particularly regret any of the choices I've made, because frankly, my options sucked.  Trying desperately to hang on to post-docs for a few more years of poverty with little to no light at the end of the tunnel wouldn't have been so great either.

text: <@U6Z8377N2> I can only answer from my own experience. I got my PhD in may 2018. Did two postdocs of like 8-12 months. Totally independent, It was explicit that I could do whatever I wanted. They also had projects that I could work on if I wanted, which I did. But majority of my time was on my own projects. Then I got a 3 year grant to do my own thing. Then I got a TT position after a couple of months (and started 3 days ago). I literally had zero mentorship during this time. Most of it I wasn't even in the same country. So for me the independence was important.

text:
In my postdoc, many of my colleagues had _awful_ experiences (extremely combative relationship with supervisors, not publishing at all). I was lucky: me and my supervisor got on well enough and I managed to get some (mediocre) papers out.

Ironically, I was the one who went to industry, while my colleagues, who had a tougher time, stayed in academia. One went to a postdoc, where they have developed a strong relationship with their supervisor and published prolifically; another to MIT for another postdoc; another got TT straight off.

In industry, I've been pining for a return to academia, and I just dropped down to part time so I can pursue a part time postdoc.

So two morals, maybe: 1) there's light at the end of the tunnel (if my colleagues' experiences are anything to go by) 2) jumping into industry is not necessarily a commital thing.

Happy to have a discussion via DM if you ever feel like it.

text:
<@U6Z8377N2> I wanted to touch upon the mental health and feeling like a failure aspect. I'm an undergrad and I don't know much about academia at all. But I want to share my experiences with these feelings of failure and some of my own treatment and my own experiences progressing through them.

Last year at the beginning of the pandemic in my city, I had to change my plans darastically. I thought I was going to graduate from my undergrad degree. But because of terrible mental health, I had to delay my graduation. When I did this I felt a lot shame and embarassment from it. I saw my friends graduate and "move on" with their lives. It bothered me. It made me feel like a failure. I got into a very negative loop and couldn't do things that I wanted to anymore.

I wanted to hide the truth from people. But thankfully overtime that shame died down a bit enough that I felt more ready to open up to friends about my new path in life, delaying my graduation, and my mental health struggles. When I did this, all my friends and everyone I talked to were all supportive and cared for me. They never thought of me as a failure, and that helped a lot with my mental health. It helped quesh those feelings of being a failure.

Around this same period of time when I got into a very negative loop about myself. I couldn't focus properly on what I had to do. So I reached to doctors and mental health professionals. And I'm so so glad I did so. I got medication and some counselling. And I love it. It just feels nice to talk about my feelings and worries and concerns with an "external" person. With my counsellor, there's absolutely no judgement. They prompt me with questions to help me explore my own thoughts and emotions and help me with develop different perspectives on life and different techniques to help me in my life. I always feel energized after talking with my counsellor. I truly believe that everyone would have something to gain from talking with a mental health professional. (Thankfully my university offers counselling to undergrads as part of tuition.)

And now in this "new" path in my life (delaying my graduation), I realized also that I can really make the most of it. I have now used this year and time to try to focus on my health more and develop more skills and gain new experiences. I've been working on my Julia more and got into a really interesting optimization class that I didn't take before.

So in summary:
- Talking about my experiences with others helped me not feel like a failure. Many people I opened up to also shared their own mental health struggles.  And honestly in hindsight, I realized I was not a "failure" (whatever that means) even though I thought I was. And thankfully everyone in my life that I've talked to has always been so kind and supportive.
- Mental health professionals can really help! I love talking to my counsellor to help me explore my own emotions and gain new perspectives
- Going through a "new" path in life made me realize that the world is full of different opportunities and that if I keep an eye out, I'll keep finding more opportunities that might be even more enjoyable than the ones I missed.

I hope and wish for you all the best! If you have any questions feel free to let me know or DM me if you want to chat

I just left a TT job for industry.  It was a pretty gut-wrenching decision to make but I think it was right for me.  I wrote about it a bit here: <https://www.davekleinschmidt.com/blog/quitlit/>

What I can add on top of that is that everyone (including my mentors) who I was worried would be disappointed in me has been uniformly enthusiastic and supportive (and in some cases, a little jealous).  It sounds like you're in a pretty toxic setting for your postdoc and like others have said, you might feel differently if you can get to a better situation there.  But it can be really hard to disentangle the feelings that come from identifying as an academic from the actual pros/cons for you personally (especially if like me you haven't had a lot of experience "on the outside").  So my advice there is to find folks with similar background on the outside and talk to them about their experiences, as a way of trying to peer across that event horizon

Industry isn't bad. Leaving TT/PD's doesn't make you a failure. Leaving a Ph.D. doesn't make you a failure.

Your PI is what we call a "blackhole". I had a PhD advisor that was the same way. It was horrible I had to switch groups. I almost left with my masters. Do you have any mentors at the school you could ask advice from? Can you switch positions?

I'm in industry now - its rough, but you make a lot of ca-ching.
